Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Direct Anterior and Direct Lateral Approaches in Total Hip Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: In this randomised controlled trial, 164 patients with end-stage osteoarthritis were recruited

Participants.evidence: 164 patients with end-stage osteoarthritis were recruited from January 2012 to June 2013

Intervention.evidence: randomised to either the direct anterior or direct lateral approach

Objective.evidence: This study compares these approaches regarding patient-reported outcomes, abductor weakness, and major complications.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the Harris hip score (HHS) measured at 3, 6, 12, and 24 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Assessors were blinded to the surgical approach.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 164 patients with end-stage osteoarthritis were recruited from January 2012 to June 2013

Number_Analysed.evidence: One hundred fifty-four patients (94%) completed the 2-year follow-up, with five patients from each group lost to follow-up. Analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: A higher proportion of patients had a positive Trendelenburg test at 24 months in the lateral approach group (16% [12 of 75] vs. 1% [one of 79]; odds ratio, 15; p = 0.001).

Harms.evidence: Four major nerve injuries occurred in the anterior group (three transient femoral nerve injuries and one persistent tibial nerve injury), with none in the lateral group.
